1.heading: Talks.
1.title: "Good Talk, Granddad. Have Fun with the Lawn"
1.author: Aaron McGruder.
notes: Summary: Granddad tries to suggest that Huey should mow the lawn.

2.heading: Talks.
2.title: "Harvard Man to Harvard Man"
2.author: G
notes: Summary: The warden wants to have a talk with Phil.

3.heading: Talks.
3.title: "If I Find Out You're Lying, You'll Wish You'd Admitted It"
3.author: Jenkins & Burns.
notes: Summary: Gil has Jack and Josh in his office for a talk about the slashed tires.

4.heading: Talks.
4.title: "Let's Have a Little Talk" 1 p. in Aline and Bob's Dirty Laundry Comics
4.author: by R
4.appears_in: Crumb and A. Kominsky (San Francisco : Cartoonists' Co-op Press, 1974).
notes: Inside front cover.

5.heading: Talks.
5.title: "Remind Me to Have a Little Talk With You Guys Later About the Order of This Rescue, Okay?"
5.author: by Chip Dunham.
notes: Summary: The cabin is on fire, and the crew brings out Louie (the dog), the television set, the dog food, and then the captain.

6.heading: Talks.
6.title: "Shut the Door. We Need to Talk about what You've Done"
6.author: Scott Adams.
notes: Summary: The boss calls Dilbert to his office, then leaves him hanging as the phone rings and time stops.

7.heading: Talks.
7.title: "Some of Blaine's Strongest Writing Occurs When He's in Bed"
7.author: by Jerry Van Amerongen.
notes: Summary: Connie is practicing a motivational talk in bed, with an easel and microphone.

8.heading: Talks.
8.title: "You'd Better Stop Stashing Snacks for a While!"
8.author: Russell Myers.
notes: Summary: Grandpa says that Locomotive (the horse) is getting expensive to feed, and Perky has a talk with him.

9.title: "The Talks are Over : King Features to Keep a New York Office ; Downsizing, Outsourcing Continues as Scheduled"

notes: (News Watch)

13.title: Superhero
13.author: Marc Tauss.
notes: 1 v. : ill. ; 27 cm.
Summary (from OCLC): Maleek and his robot Marvyn travel to the past to find trees and plants to restore the city that tall buildings have taken over.
Superhero fiction.

14.heading: Tall Buildings.
14.title: "Upwardly Mobile"
14.author: by Eric Drooker
14.appears_in: cover of The New Yorker, v. 72, no. 29 (Sept. 30, 1996).
notes: Summary: Man surrounded by tall buildings sees a bird high above.

15.heading: Tall Grass.
15.title: "Bad Argument"
15.author: by Jimmy Johnson.
notes: Summary: Arlo tries to avoid mowing the lawn by saying that tall grass is a good wildlife habitat.

16.heading: Tall Grass.
16.title: "Can You Cradle His Head a Little?"
16.author: by Chip Dunham.
notes: Summary: The ball knocks the captain out in the tall grass, but they lift him up and are able to play it.

17.heading: Tall Grass.
17.title: "Finally Getting Around to Cutting My Lawn"
17.author: by Stephen Bentley.
notes: Summary: Herb's neighbor Mr. Torpid is cutting his tall grass with hedge clippers.

18.heading: Tall Grass.
18.title: "Gosh, What a Lovely Sunset!"
18.author: A
notes: Summary: Out for a walk, his owners overlook an expanse of fields and meadows while Fred, in the tall grass, can't see a thing.

19.heading: Tall Grass.
19.title: "I Am the Swamp Fairy. Throw in 5 Clams and I'll Toss Your Ball Out"
19.author: by Johnny Hart.
notes: Summary: The golfers have lost a ball in the tall grass.

20.heading: Tall Grass.
20.title: "I Couldn't Stand To See Him So Happy"
20.author: Dik Browne
20.appears_in: reproduced (p. 221) in The Best of Hi and Lois, by Mort Walker and Dik Browne (Bedford, N.Y. : Comicana Books, 1986)
notes: Summary: Thirsty's wife thinks about divorce. We see him in his lawn chair in the tall grass of his lawn.

21.heading: Tall Grass.
21.title: "I Don't Believe You Two Have Met"
21.author: by Ted Key.
notes: Summary: Hazel has brought the lawnmower out into the tall grass to the man in the lawn chair.

22.heading: Tall Grass.
22.title: "I Think It's Time to Mow the Lawn, Paul"
22.author: Gilbert.
notes: Summary: Buckles is playing hyena. He steals hamburgers from the picnic table of the lions, and disappears into the tall grass of the African plains.

23.heading: Tall Grass.
23.title: "I Think Your Granddad May Be Onto Something With This Whole 'Lawn Care' Thing"
23.author: Aaron McGruder.
notes: Summary: They're trying to play soccer in the yard, but the grass is so tall they can't see the ball.

24.heading: Tall Grass.
24.title: "I'll Do the Other Half Tomorrow"
24.author: Breen.
notes: Summary: Michael has mowed half the lawn, leaving strips of tall grass.

25.heading: Tall Grass.

25.author: Jim Davis.
notes: Summary: The grass is so tall you can't see out the front window.

26.heading: Tall Grass.

notes: Summary: A man hits his golf ball, and his dog finds it in the tall grass.

52.heading: Tallandier.
52.title: Les Maîtres de la Caricature : Aquarelles et Dessins Inédits de Alb. Guillaume, F. Bac, Ch. Huard, H. Gerbault, Caran d'Ache, C. Léandre, Job, B. Rabier, Abel Faivre, A. Robida, Steinlen, Hermann Paul, Balluriau, Forain, Lucien Métivet, etc., etc.
52.author: préface de Roger-Milès.
notes: The reproductions from the work of each artist are accompanied by a short prose sketch by Lucien Puech, except for Rabier and Willette who introduce themselves. The name of J. Grün, one of the artists covered, is missing from the list on the title page, though the title vignette is by him. The final album is titled "La Pléiade des Jeunes" and introduces 14 younger artists.
Covers of five issues of L'Album, from which this volume is compiled, are bound at end.

100.title: "Taller de Perro : Por una Historieta de Autor : 7o Encuentro Internacional de Historietistas"
100.author: Ernesto Priego
100.appears_in: p. 63-67 in Revista Latinoamericana de Estudios sobre la Historieta, v. 2, no. 6 (Junio 2002).
notes: Resumen: "Breve conocimiento de la batalla emprendida por un editor y un grupo de entusiastas artistas por lograr una prespuesta alternative en un territorio signado por la hegemonía de comercialismo y donde se logró construir un proyecto conciso y coherente a través de Gallito Comics a partir de 1991."

Summary: Since 1991 a publisher and a group of young Mexican artists have worked hard to find an alternative in the field of comics, a territory dominated by commercialism, and have built a very focused and coherent project, Gallito Comics.
Abstracts as printed with the article, with some editing of the English.
Includes illustrations.

101.heading: Taller de Perro--Articles About.
101.title: "La Onomatoepopeya : 7o Encuentro Internacional de Historietistas"
101.author: Ricardo Peláez
101.appears_in: p. 68-74 in Revista Latinoamericana de Estudios sobre la Historieta, v. 2, no. 6 (Junio 2002).
notes: Resumen: "El Taller de Perro resultó un tránsito desde Gallito Comics para los jóvenes artistas que proponían otra alternative de lectura del cómic y que halló un eco favorable en un reducido grupo de lectores, fiel exigente. Hay aquí un ejemplo posible de imitar y obtener resultados en otras fronteras."

Summary: The Taller del Perro is a development from Gallito Comics by a group of young artists who wanted a comics reading alternative, and who found their small group of faithful readers. Here we have an example that can possibly be imitated with good results elsewhere.
Abstracts as printed with the article, with some editing of the English.
Includes illustrations.

138.heading: Talon, Tom.
138.title: "Wingmate of Doom!"
138.author: Robert Kanigher, script ; Jerry Grandenetti, art
138.appears_in: 13 p. in All American Men of War, no. 90 (Mar./Apr. 1962).
notes: Summary: Johnny leaves his patrol when Tex spots an unknown Mustang about to be ambushed by a Messerschmitt. It turns out the Mustang pilot didn't need help, but when Johnny returns to his flight it's surrounded by German fighters. Johnny's unexpected return saves the day, and back at the base the new pilot reports. His name is Lt. Tom Talon, and like Cloud he is Native American. The other pilots observe the meeting of the two men with these comments: "Look at the dead-pan way those two are looking at each other!" "Just like Indians! Never showing what they feel!" We learn that as boys the two men played together on the reservation, and that Talon's brother died during one of their games and Cloud is unfairly blamed for the death. Talon has sworn to kill Cloud, though the other men don't know this. On the next mission Johnny Cloud makes Talon his wingman, demoting a disapproving Tex to no. 3. Talon saves Cloud's life after first putting it in jeopardy. The next day Cloud saves Talon's life nearly at the expense of his own, and lands barely alive in enemy territory. Talon lands to pick him up, and they make it to safety even though being fired upon by a German tank. Talon considers the fact that Cloud saved his life to be payment of the debt for his brother's life.
Data from Bob Klein, via Grand Comics Database Project.
